forecast.review: The other forecasters introduced several crucial points I had overlooked. Both convincingly argued for mean-reversion after the large +7.6% increase in March, a statistical tendency I had not sufficiently weighted. Forecaster 2 provided new, concrete negative regional data on bankruptcies and business sentiment, which tempers the optimistic Bank of Japan report I had relied on. Most importantly, Forecaster 3 introduced the preliminary nationwide industrial production data for April, which showed a 0.9% decline. This is a highly significant piece of macro evidence that directly contradicts the narrative of continued growth. I also found Forecaster 2's clarification on the timing of Golden Week helpful; its impact on April is likely minimal, removing one of my original (and apparently incorrect) justifications for a potential decline.
forecast.rationale: I am significantly updating my forecast downward. My initial 55% forecast was too high, overly influenced by a single positive regional report and sector-specific optimism. The arguments from the other forecasters have convinced me that a decline is now the more likely outcome. The two most decisive factors are new to my analysis. First, the preliminary nationwide Industrial Production Index for April showed a decline of 0.9%. It is difficult for a region to post a gain when the national trend is negative. Second, the argument for mean-reversion after an exceptionally large +7.6% jump in March is statistically very strong; such volatile series rarely post large consecutive gains. These two factors, combined with the weaker underlying regional data on bankruptcies and business sentiment mentioned by Forecaster 2, now outweigh the positive, forward-looking statements about the semiconductor industry. While that sector might still perform well, it is unlikely to be strong enough to overcome both a national downturn and statistical reversion. I have therefore moved my forecast from a slightly optimistic 55% to a moderately pessimistic 40%.
